articles.headline: Inside the Blunders That Plunged the College Admission Season Into Disarray
articles.snippet: The Education Department was supposed to make applying for federal financial aid easier. Instead, it got worse.
articles.abstract: The Education Department was supposed to make applying for federal financial aid easier. Instead, it got worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were just days left to process a batch of federal financial aid applications when Education Department officials made a fateful discovery: 70,000 emails from students all over the country, containing reams of essential data.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Zach Montague

articles.headline: U.K. Moves to Bar Foreign State Ownership of Newspapers, a Blow to Telegraph Bid
articles.snippet: A roughly $1 billion bid from the former CNN chief Jeff Zucker and his Emirati backers raised concerns among lawmakers over a storied conservative newspaper.
articles.abstract: A roughly $1 billion bid from the former CNN chief Jeff Zucker and his Emirati backers raised concerns among lawmakers over a storied conservative newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: An audacious effort by the American media executive Jeff Zucker and his Emirati backers to acquire London’s Daily Telegraph appeared to be on life support on Wednesday after the British government advanced legislation that would bar foreign state ownership of newspapers and newsmagazines.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Mark Landler

articles.headline: A Corvette, Swimsuit Shots and a Trip to Mongolia: Biden Offers a Tour of His Life
articles.snippet: Transcripts of five hours of interviews with the special counsel released this week reveal a president with a lot on his mind and a storehouse of stories to tell.
articles.abstract: Transcripts of five hours of interviews with the special counsel released this week reveal a president with a lot on his mind and a storehouse of stories to tell.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were there to talk about classified documents, but somehow President Biden’s mind had turned to Mongolia.

articles.headline: Lawyer, Author and TikTok Star Spent 72 Years in an Iron Lung
articles.snippet: Paul Alexander, who died at 78, was paralyzed with polio at age 6 and relied on the machine to breathe. Still, he was able to earn a law degree, write a book and, late in life, build a following on TikTok.
articles.abstract: Paul Alexander, who died at 78, was paralyzed with polio at age 6 and relied on the machine to breathe. Still, he was able to earn a law degree, write a book and, late in life, build a following on TikTok.
articles.lead_paragraph: After he was paralyzed by polio at age 6, Paul Alexander was confined for much of his life to a yellow iron lung that kept him alive. He was not expected to survive after that diagnosis, and even when he beat those odds, his life was mostly constrained by a machine in which he could not move.

articles.headline: Can Europe Save Forests Without Killing Jobs in Malaysia?
articles.snippet: A new regulation aims to rid the palm oil supply chain of imports that come from former forestland. Southeast Asian countries say it threatens livelihoods.
articles.abstract: A new regulation aims to rid the palm oil supply chain of imports that come from former forestland. Southeast Asian countries say it threatens livelihoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union’s upcoming ban on imports linked to deforestation has been hailed as a “gold standard” in climate policy: a meaningful step to protect the world’s forests, which help remove planet-killing greenhouse gases from the atmosphere.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Jes Aznar

articles.headline: Snakes in the Grass — and Under the Piano, by the Pool and in the Prison
articles.snippet: Business is good for snake catchers in Australia, as the period of brumation, a sort of hibernation for reptiles, is shrinking — a result of the warming earth.
articles.abstract: Business is good for snake catchers in Australia, as the period of brumation, a sort of hibernation for reptiles, is shrinking — a result of the warming earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: The phone rings. It’s the local prison. There’s a snake in a cell. Within a few hours, snakes have also been spotted at a school, beneath a piano stored in a private garage and near a lagoon-like swimming pool at a retirement home. Customers want them gone.
articles.byline: By Natasha Frost and David Maurice Smith

articles.headline: One Big Reason Gen Z Is Still on Facebook: To Save Money
articles.snippet: For a generation that loves thrift-shopping, Facebook isn’t a place to socialize online — it’s the best place to score some deals.
articles.abstract: For a generation that loves thrift-shopping, Facebook isn’t a place to socialize online — it’s the best place to score some deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December, Ellicia Chiu and Cher Su had just a few boxes in tow when they moved into a walk-up apartment in New York’s Lower East Side neighborhood. Before their move, from Los Angeles, the two friends knew that they would need to furnish their new apartment with small kitchen appliances, décor and furniture. But instead of purchasing new items, they knew it would be more affordable to find secondhand items on Facebook Marketplace, the social network’s buy-and-sell service.

articles.headline: TikTok Turns to Creators to Fight Possible Ban
articles.snippet: Dozens of popular figures on the app have traveled to Washington to urge lawmakers to oppose a bill that could result in the platform being blocked in the United States.
articles.abstract: Dozens of popular figures on the app have traveled to Washington to urge lawmakers to oppose a bill that could result in the platform being blocked in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing a possible ban in the United States, TikTok has scrambled to deploy perhaps its most powerful weapon: its creators.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Yiwen Lu

articles.headline: Schumer Urges New Leadership in Israel, Calling Netanyahu an Obstacle to Peace
articles.snippet: The top Senate Democrat, the highest-ranking Jewish elected official in the United States, spoke from the Senate floor to condemn Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and call for elections to replace him.
articles.abstract: The top Senate Democrat, the highest-ranking Jewish elected official in the United States, spoke from the Senate floor to condemn Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and call for elections to replace him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, on Thursday delivered a pointed speech on the Senate floor excoriating Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel as a major obstacle to peace in the Middle East and calling for new leadership in Israel, five months into the war.

articles.headline: Cities Face Cutbacks as Commercial Real Estate Prices Tumble
articles.snippet: Lost tax revenue fuels concerns over an urban ‘doom loop.’
articles.abstract: Lost tax revenue fuels concerns over an urban ‘doom loop.’
articles.lead_paragraph: In San Francisco, a 20-story office tower that sold for $146 million a decade ago was listed in December for just $80 million.
